title.narrative: Provision of essential MHPSS and emergency health services in response to the COVID-19 in selected priority districts

description.narrative:
Through the AHF 3rd Reserve Allocation 2020, HNI-TPO will provide essential emergency health services in response to the COVID-19 outbreak, consisting of risk communication and Mental Health and Psych-Social Support (MHPSS) services in Kabul, Nangarhar, Ghor, Farah and Nimroz provinces, and will establish and operate isolation wards in two urban District Hospitals (DHs) in Kabul city. The target areas were selected in view of the priorities identified by Health Cluster based on the current concentration of COVID-19, and the current geographic presence of HNI-TPO. The project will be specifically addressing the needs of COVID-19-affected persons and will be implemented in coordination with other stakeholders and projects in the target provinces to avoid duplication and operational conflict. As the COVID-19 is mostly concentrated in urban areas of the five provinces, the envisaged set of activities will be expanded to rural areas of the target provinces when needed.
The project activities will consist of the following approaches. 1. Establishment and operation of 11 COVID-19 Outreach Teams (3 in Kabul, 2 in Nangarhar, 2 in Ghor, 2 in Farah, and 2 in Nimroz) which will provide Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) activities as recommended by the RCCE Working Group, and targeted MHPSS services to COVID-19 patients and those who are at high risk (family members of patients, elderly and women). 2. Establishment and operation of one Isolation Ward in each of Rahman Mina DH and Tanikot DH in Kabul city, each with the capacity of 5 beds.. Owing to the lack of required services through urban health facilities in Kabul city, the PPHD has highlighted the need for treatment of critically-ill COVID-19 patients through isolation ward services in eastern part of the city. The services will be based on the recommendations of MoPH and WHO. 3. Provision of protective gear to the urban public health facilities in Kabul city, as there is no or little focus to these health facilities in the government response according to the Kabul PPHD. 4. Provision of MHPSS through 17 urban health facilities in Kabul city. Among the 36 CHCs, only 9 of them have Psycho-Social Counselor (PSC) in their staffing structure. Through another project of HNI-TPO in the past, 36 PSCs were trained for Kabul city but only 9 of them were deployed. Based on the recommendation of Kabul PPHD, 17 urban health facilities will be staffed with the already-trained PSCs to provided targeted MHPSS services to COVID-19-affected people. 5. Provision of RCCE services through local radio and TV in the five provinces, and the establishment of Facebook information page within PPHD office in the target provinces. The choice of using radio or TV in the provinces will depends on which channel is more effective in view of the availability of COVID-19 RCCE broadcast by other stakeholders, and which communication has been chosen by beneficiaries in the REACH mapping. Based on the REACH mapping, radio will be a preferable communication channel in Nangarhar, while both radio and TV will be considered in Ghor, Farah and Nimroz. There will be no radio/TV activity in Kabul.
The project will be implemented through a dedicated team in coordination with PPHDs and the Health Cluster. The established standards and guidelines of MoPH and WHO will be considered as the basis of RCCE and COVID-19 response services. Supervision and monitoring will be integral part of the project activities which will be carried out through the existing setup of HNI-TPO in the five provinces under the oversight of the MampE department of the organization.
Special attention will be given to the particular needs of women and elderly as these two have been identified at-risk groups in the context of COVID-19 in Afghanistan. The project strategies and activities are geared to the needs of the two groups.

title.narrative: Increasing community resilience against Covid-19 and reducing its effects among the most vulnerable Afghan communities in Kandahar, Nimroz, and Herat Provinces

description.narrative: This project seeks to decrease the mortality and morbidity of Covid-19 among IDP, returnee, and host communities for people with disabilities and the most vulnerable in Herat, Kandahar, and Nimroz. It will do this by 1) Support risk communication interventions to help ensure that clear communication messaging on COVID-19 is widely available to all communities through vehicle messaging, billboards, radio spots, accessible IEC materials, SMS and other identified means, 2) Providing mental health support to affected communities through a helpline as well as providing mental health containment kits to identified families, and conducting an awareness campaign about mental health issues and Covid-19, 3) Support health facilities with both infection prevention and control materials as well as with psychosocial support and risk awareness to health facility staff For this action, gender balanced teams will be working in two districts in Herat, one district in Nimroz, and two districts in Kandahar. The action will be implemented in close coordination with other actors providing health services, as well as with other actors providing basic health and protection services in the project locations through a referral mechanism. The technical teams are supported by the Project Officer and the Data base officer within each base. The action targets health facility staff as well as at risk populations, including the women, men, girls and boys at risk of exclusion, people with disabilities, people with injuries, people experiencing psychosocial distress or mental health issues– due to Covid-19, who are often invisible to mainstream relief organizations due to the specificity of their needs. The above interventions are aimed at reducing the vulnerability of communities to Covid-19, and increasing the capacity to respond whilst reinforcing positive coping mechanisms

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: CARE COVID-19 Response through Mobile Health Team in Urban and Rural Areas of Balkh and Kabul provinces.

description.narrative: CARE Afghanistan proposes to meet the emergency needs of 9,000 vulnerable households (63,000 individuals) potentially to be affected by COVID-19 in at-risk communities of IDPs, informal settlement, and marginalized communities in 9 districts across the provinces of Kabul and Balkh. The project will support the target communities by providing access to information IEC materials, awareness-raising session, and strong community engagement on COVID-19. Services will further include community- based surveillance of COVID-19 cases, case identification and referral, provision of guidance and dissemination of guidelines on COVID-19 including case definition and case management to BPHS, EPHS and private health facilities and surveillance teams as well as the provision of stockpiles of PPEs and consumables to the mentioned health facilities. Moreover, the project will include a provision of psycho-social counseling and awareness-raising to reduce fear, rumors, and stigma among affected communities. CARE has had a long presence in the two provinces of Kabul and Balkh and implemented various health and humanitarian projects. This intervention is building on the experience of previous health-related projects including recent GAC’s funded Emergency Response project, where MHTs have been used to provide support to vulnerable families, women and children in particular, with increased health services, as well as OFDA’s funded Drought Response project where community-based surveillance of communicable diseases and malnutrition was established and conducted in Balkh and Samangan Provinces. CARE has implemented mobile health team projects for the provision of life-saving SRH and PHC in the two provinces and has strong linkages with the communities, as most of the CARE interventions are community-based. The project will be implemented through Mobile Health Teams (MHT) in the targeted districts, the MHTs staffing, scope of work and medical commodities will be aligned with the MHT package of health services outlined by the MoPH for emergency response. Also, the MHTs’ achievements will be reported to the Health Information Management System (HIMS) of MoPH. Each MHT will comprise a team of professionals, including a medical doctor to conduct community-based screening and case identification of COVID-19 cases along with the provision of life-saving primary health care services and to provide technical support to the local health facilities on COVID-19 guidelines, a midwife to provide maternal and neonatal health services, a psychosocial counselor, who will provide psychosocial counseling services for the beneficiaries affected by fear and stigma due to COVID-19 as well as due to GBV, a vaccinator to provide immunization services, and two community mobilizers (one male and one female), who will be conducted community awareness-raising, training of the community members on COVID-19 and to support psychosocial counselor on psychosocial awareness-raising sessions. CARE will deploy our existing technical staff on the mobile teams, who have solid local experience. This project will provide opportunities for COVID-19 testing, referral, treatment, and counseling as well as technical support from the MHT teams. CARE will be implementing this project in close coordination and agreement with the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) of Afghanistan. Several meetings have been held with Provincial Public Health Directorates of both Kabul and Balkh provinces and both are in agreement with and supportive of the proposed project. CARE is also encouraging to seek further opportunities to expand the services to wider areas.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Response through Health Support for the People at risk in Kabul, Herat, Kandahar, Balkh and Nangarhar provinces in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The proposed project is aiming contribute to the lifesaving efforts including reducing the impact of COVID-19 in in Kabul, Heat, Kandahar, Balkh and Nangarhar provinces in Afghanistan through community engagement, identifying the COVID-19 cases and referral to existing health facilities, mass awareness raising through different communication channel, and production and dissemination of Information Education Communication (IEC) materials for raising public awareness. The project is designed as per the needs and gaps identified by the health cluster for the AHF 3rd Reserved Allocation 2020. The project will reach out to 60,000 direct beneficiaries at risk (women-21,000, men-18,000, girls-10,800, boys-10,200) and 100,000 indirect beneficiaries in targeted districts in in Kabul, Herat, Kandahar, Balkh and Nangarhar provinces. The project focuses on providing support to the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) to better respond to the unprecedented health situation. The project will also equip MoPH with COVID-19 dedicated ambulances at each province to be used for transfer of COVID patients/suspects from/to house, hospitals, and quarantine centers to help provide standard service and avoid its spread. The project also aims to raise awareness of people at large particularly those in high risk areas about how to protect themselves from COVID-19 and its spread to others.
The project will use it Faith Driven Approach (FDA) to mobilize people and make them aware why and how to protect from the pandemic from the religious perspective, Afghanistan being a strong conservative and religious society. Women and men Community leaders, religious leader and community health workers and members of CDCs will be actively engaged while using FM radio, TV and other communication tools. MoPH approved messages on COVID-19 will be disseminated, safe and sustained communications channels will be followed through engagement of local community. RCCE WG will be communicated regular basis for setting the communication methodologies and tools. IRW will ensure coordination with RCCE WG to ensure mode of risk communication and community engagement, and rumor tracking.
This six-month project will arrange community outreach and awareness raising activities. The project will disseminate COVID-19 awareness messages through local FM radios, TV Channels, and Cable TV Networks. The project will also interact with the Faith Leaders (Imam), community leaders, and women leaders through engaging them to motivate people individually so that the COVID-19 awareness messages can be reached in the remote rural areas. The project will also provide precautionary and protection measures on COVID-19 to the project staff to ensure their safety and avoid the transmission of the virus to the project beneficiaries. The project will distribute COVID-19 specific health items to the highly vulnerable families in the targeted areas so that they can protect themselves from COVID19 and from further spreading. The project team will help with referral of cases to MoPH/DoPHs through gathering information about any person with symptoms of COVID19 via mobile call by local elders or community leaders or CDC. Regarding the logistic support, the project will pay cost for ambulance for bringing the suspected patient to hospital.
IRW in Afghanistan has field offices and strong presence in the proposed provinces including community acceptance and government trust. IRW is already implementing projects from donors like UNOCHA and our other partners in these areas. IR Afghanistan has already started COVID-19 response through distributing health kits, PPEs, N95 Masks, continued awareness raising through local FM radios, distributing leaflets, maintaining close collaboration with the relevant Health and other Clusters including Ministry of Public Health (MoPH). The project will be implemented in close coordination with the MoPH, UNOCHA, Health Cluster and other stakeholders.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of lifesaving health and nutrition services in COVID-19 high risk districts of Herat province

description.narrative: The proposed project aims to respond to the population affected by COVID-19 through provision of integrated health and nutrition services in 11 priority districts of Herat province Kohsan district ( Islam Qala) Ghoryan, Gulran, Guzara, Hirat, Injil, Karukh, Kohsan, Kushk(Robat Sangi), Obe, Pashtun Zarghun and Shindand. AADA will undertake the following key interventions: Health: All staff involved in this project will be trained to support Risk Communications amp Community Engagement to increase public awareness on COVID-19 risk mitigation, positive coping strategies and social cohesion using the MOPH approved Information Education and Communication (IEC) materials through community health workers (CHWs), outreach social workers, mobile health and nutrition teams (MHNT) and available platforms/communication channels. Tracking of the rumors, feedback, concerns and questions and their sources, and share with Risk Communication and Community Engagement Working Group RCCE WG will be done through this project. In total 1574 (780 male and 794 female) CHWs will trained on community based response who will then conduct a four hours orientation session on COVID-19 prevention and positive coping strategies to an estimated 47,720 (23760 male and 23760 female) community members including religious leaders in 792 remote villages. Each session will consist of 20 participant considering infection prevention measures and physical distance. Under this action, capacity of existing 29 remote Basic Health Center (BHC) and Health Sub-Center (HSC) will be enhanced by recruiting two outreach social workers (male and female) in each -to conduct outreach screening/referral and community awareness of preventive activities and tracing of the people who were in contact with confirmed cases of COVID-19. Given the existing gaps in ambulance services for COVID-19 suspected cases, nine well-equipped ambulance units will be established in nine of 11 target districts to support referring of suspected cases to nearest hospitals and rapid response teams ( funded by World Bank ) in the district centers for testing and further follow-up -including evacuation to isolation centers. Infection prevention and control measures will be supported at the health facilities level by establishing hand washing facilities and provision of personal protection equipment (PPE) and hygiene products to front line health and nutrition workers. Ambulance unit with two nurses (one male and one female)will be established in Islam Qala entry point to support the existing HFs in zero point in screening the incoming people from Iran and immediate refer of suspected case to nearest hospital. Nutrition: Five MHNTs will be established and maintained in underserved areas of five COVID-19 high risk districts (Kohsan, Kushk (Robat Sangi), Obe, Pashtun Zarghun and Shindand) to provide Outpatient Department of Severe Acute Malnutrition (OPD-SAM), Outpatient Department of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (OPD-MAM), services to acutely malnourished boys and girls (6 to 59 months) and Acutely Malnourished Pregnant and Lactating Women (AM PLW), Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) to children under five years old age, primary health care including immunization to boys , girls , men and women IYCF-E and Maternal, Infant and Young Child Nutrition (MIYCN) counselling services to target beneficiaries . Nutrition sites will be established by recruiting nutrition female nurses in 15 HSCs remote to implement Blanket Supplementary Food (BSF) distribution to protect the nutritional status of children 5-59 months and PLWs. In total 348 male and 353 female CHWs will be trained for three days on nutrition basics and IYCF-E counselling to enable them to provide IYCF-E counselling to mothers/caregivers in the catchment area of the health post (HPs).

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: To reduce further transmission of COVID-19 and reduce mortality and morbidity caused by severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in targeted high risk districts in context of COVID-19 in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
Health: Afghanistan remains a protracted complex emergency and is frequently affected by natural disasters leading to significant loss of lives, livelihoods as well as reversion of developmental gains. On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia of unknown etiology was reported in Wuhan City, Hubei Province of China. On 9 January 2020 Chinese authorities reported in the media that the cause of this viral pneumonia was initially identified as a new type of corona-virus. The situation has further affected when the local transmission moved globally with highest number of confirmed cases and deaths reported from Iran and Italy after China with multiple global hot spots. WHO expects that in the days and weeks ahead, we might see the number of cases, the number of deaths, and the number of affected countries climb even higher. On 11 March 2020, WHO declared COVID-19 a pandemic.
Afghanistan has been affected by the virus with having already the local transmission of COVID-19 with 33 out of 34 provinces already reported the cases. Slowing the transmission of COVID-19 and protecting communities requires participation of every member of at-risk and affected communities. It is therefore essential that national, and local authorities engage through participatory two-way communication efforts proactively, regularly, transparently and unambiguously with all affected and at-risk populations. Ability to engage and mobilize communities find, test, and isolate cases provide effective clinical care and maintain essential health services differs according to the capacity and context both nationally and regionally, as well as the intensity and prevalence of COVID-19 transmissions. Residents of high-density informal settlements find it especially hard or even impossible to comply with physical distancing measures and movement restrictions. The treatment of large volumes of patients with COVID-19 in existing health facilities is not possible, and widespread testing, contact tracing and quarantine measures may prove challenging without major, rapid and coordinated capacity strengthening.
There are nine priority areas that WHO plans to cover on the overall COVID-19 response. Under the AHF Reserve Allocation, the following two thematic health areas are covered: 1) Strengthen and enhance the capacity of national laboratories for sample collection and testing 2) Risk communication and community engagement
Nutrition: The Nutrition cluster has prioritized the activities as described in the COVID-19 Multi-Sector Country Plan. Strengthening the capacity of inpatient services is also part of the priorities. As of now, 26 high-risk districts are prioritized. These districts are also identified by DTM-IOM as high risks districts for COVID-19 on the Iranian border side. They are also HRP districts. The SAM cases with medical complicated need life-saving treatment services through inpatient facilities, which is in line of cluster HRP SO1 and CovId 19 Multi-Sectoral humanitarian country plan. The intervention will strengthen operational and staff’s functional capacity in the 24 IPD-SAM that provide treatment and care for children with complicated Severe Acute Malnutrition in the context of COVID-19 . Health workers in the targeted IPD-SAM will receive training on inpatient management of SAM, breastfeeding, hygiene as well as on infection prevention and control for the beneficiaries and health workers themselves. The targeted IPD-SAM will undergo assessment followed by functional upgrading, through the provision/replacement of F-75/F-100 milk preparation kits, which are essential in the management of the malnourished children. Equipment including medical equipment,medicine ,milk preparation kit, and cold chain and warming system, bed side chairs for caregivers will to ensuring the quality and efficient continuity of services provided by the IPD-SAM centers.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response - Support to Surveillance, Risk Communication and Points of Entry

description.narrative:
Component 1: Based on identified gaps in community-level awareness leading to a reluctance to take precautions against the spread of COVID-19 in Afghanistan inclusive of a reluctance to adhere to movement restrictions, physical distancing measures and testing for sick or suspect persons, IOM proposes to expand community level risk communication and engagement through the deployment of social mobilizers in the provinces of Nangahar, Kandahar, Nimroz and Herat- four disease outbreak hubs linked to cross border returns. These teams will engage with Community Health Worker networks to ensure regular advocacy through organized sensitization campaigning with a focus on peri-urban and rural areas where information gaps remain the most pronounced. Special attention will be paid to community and religious leadership cadres.
Component 2: In discussion and agreement with the Public Health Directors in Herat, Nangarhar, Kandahar and Nimroz provinces and the health cluster/WHO in both regions, IOM will supplement existing rapid response teams (COVID sample collection teams composed of 1 doctor, 1 nurse and 1 lab tech as per the SOP developed by the Ministry of Health) by adding 11 additional teams (35 medical personnel in total) to respond to requests to collect and process COVID-19 samples from suspect cases. In order to transport these teams IOM will support their movements with ambulances which will also be used for referral to designated government isolation/hospital facilities for suspect and emergency cases.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency nutrition services in COVID-19 high risk districts of Balkh, Kunduz and Faryab provinces

description.narrative: In the proposed project, Save the Children (SC) will implement emergency nutrition and health services in four COVID-19 high risk districts of Balkh (Mazar-i-Sharif), Kunduz (Kunduz city and Imam Sahib) and Faryab (Maimana) provinces. These districts are prioritized under the COVID-19 Multisectoral Humanitarian Country Plan. The project will deploy four mobile health and nutrition teams (MHNTs) in the four priority districts (one in each district) to provide outpatient services for the management of severely and moderately acute malnourished (OPD-SAM and OPD-MAM) boys and girls (six to 59 months), management of acutely malnourished pregnant and lactating women (PLW), infant and young child feeding in emergency (IYCF-E) services, primary and reproductive health and basic psychosocial support services with the focus on under five years old children and PLW. To build resilience of vulnerable groups at borderline of acute malnutrition, children at risk of malnutrition with MUAC gt12.5 - lt13.5 will be targeted for integrated IYCF-E response. The project will provide Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) supplies to MHNTs, and hygiene kits for PLW to prevent/reduce transmission of COVID-19 in health workers, beneficiaries and PLW. Use of mothers/caregivers MUAC will be strengthened to further improve the quality of screening and early diagnosis, and reduce exposure. Based on the needs assessments, the project will develop a capacity building plan with the focus on MHNT staff training on integrated management of acute malnutrition (IMAM), IYCF-E, Nutrition Cluster guidance on IMAM and IYCF programming in the context of COVID-19, IPC in the context of COVID-19, Psychosocial First Aid (PFA) and gender equality. For MHNT staff capacity building, tele-communication system will be considered (if physical training is not possible). Additionally, the project will strengthen dissemination of key information/messages to promote and support optimal IYCF-E, good hygiene, psychosocial wellbeing, and positive coping strategies in the context of COVID-19 using different platforms/communication channels that include: printing and dissemination of IEC materials, radio, community announcement, IVR mass messaging and social media. In the implementation of the proposed interventions, SC will consider Nutrition Cluster’s guide on IMAM and IYCF program adaptation in the context of COVID-19, and SC’s operational SOP for MHNTs in the context of COVID-19 that focuses on physical adaptation of MHNTs, crowd control, IPC, identification of COVID-19 suspected cases, and staff safety. The proposed action will target 36,000 direct beneficiaries including 20,178 women and girls. The timeline for the action is from 1 June, 2020 until 30 November, 2020. SC will implement this project in coordination with all relevant actors at the national, provincial and community levels to ensure effective and timely management of the proposed interventions.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Lifesaving Nutrition support under CoVID-19 response in Herat and Badghis priority districts

description.narrative:
The designed project aims at ensuring delivery of adequate nutrition services, including the malnutrition treatment, compromised due to the movement restrictions and other stressors. The disruption of nutrition service provision due to overburdened health facilities and staff shortages associated with COVID-19 is expected to deteriorate the nutrition status of children, as well as pregnant and lactating women in the pre-defined high-risk districts (Ghoriyan, Gulran, Guzara, Enjil, Hirat, Karukh and Qala-e-now). World Vision (WV) Intends to deliver the required nutrition services through the establishment of 6 Mobile Health and Nutrition teams as well as the promotion of mother MUAC to put mothers at the center of malnutrition screening. The mother MUAC strategies acknowledge that mothers are in the best position to detect the earliest signs of malnutrition and leverages the fact that mothers want to participate as fully as possible in promoting the health and nutrition of their children. The mothers will report on MUAC screening once a month, in addition to this the project strengthening the capacity of Family Health Action Groups, female volunteers and CHWs in Infant and Young Child Feeding to promote key IYCF practices and counselling based on the WHO guideline under the COVID-19 circumstances. These groups will be trained to respond to the question of key community members and women in childbearing ages in relation on promotion of breastfeeding and be able to respond any questions that may be asked by each member of the community.
Blanket supplementary feeding is generally used as a preventive measure among PLWs and children under 2 during the COVID-19 emergency period (project duration), WVI will appeal to WFP for the BSFP supplies and distribute to the children under 2 and PLWs in the target locations. MHNTs operate 6 days per week and ensure that the SAM and MAM children are identified and admitted to the program. The SAM children will receive the RUTF and screening every 2 weeks while the MAM will receive RUSF and screening once a month.
The project will focus on early action to avoid severe malnutrition so the project will cover the, ‘borderline’ cases of acute malnutrition through prevention-oriented services such as counselling on optimal care practices to mothers of children who are borderline in terms of their Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC). This approach has potential to reduce the risk of rapid deterioration of the nutritional status of children with a MUAC result of 12.5-13.5 cm. This will be done at the MHNTs level by nutrition nurse and at the community level by community nutrition promoters.
The proposed project will ensure that all the relevant staff members and health/nutrition care providers are equipped with the PPE and IPC in order to be protected from the COVID-19 and are able to fully operate under the novel virus circumstances. The adaptation mechanism will be taken into consideration during any capacity building efforts, IYCF promotion session based on the WHO/MOPH and WV Standard Operating Procedure for training, public gatherings, IEC distribution under the COVID-19 circumstances. The project will focus on the provision of lifesaving referral for those cases that require inpatient services and will ensure that a transportation and treatment facility are provided for them. WV attends the EPR meetings on a weekly basis and will update the key actors including DoPH, UNICEF and WHO on the project progress the project report will be shared on a weekly and monthly basis to the key nutrition cluster focal points and DEWS surveillance focal points. In the EPR meetings, various issues are discussed such as places where the new MHNTs should operate and take proper measures to avoid overlap of same interventions. The locations WV is targeting via the proposed project are/shall be endorsed by EPR and are different with that of the UNCIEF MHNTs.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Treatment and prevention of moderate acute malnutrition the provinces most affected by COVID-19 in Afghanistan.

description.narrative:
The COVID-19 pandemic is currently the most critical global concern with a potential for causing the highest mortality rates across the world in 2020. With limitations in the Afghanistan’s ability to fully control the transmission especially from populations moving into the country from the neighbouring states (Iran and Pakistan), it is anticipated that the spread will continue to provinces beyond those in the immigration/cross-border belt. Just like other countries, the scale and nature of the spread of COVID-19 has so far resulted into various actions such as border closures, internal and external movement restrictions, suspension and or closure of several socio-economic activities including schools. As a result, people are cut off from their normal livelihoods, access to basic services is significantly reduced causing a drastic deterioration of food and nutrition security. Most affected are individuals who are already malnourished while many at borderline food insecurity are at the highest risk of dropping into the food insecure category resulting into a higher likelihood of getting of malnourished. It is therefore anticipated that the rates of malnutrition will rise during this period.
As part of the response, and in line with the Nutrition cluster COVID-19 response plan and priorities, WFP plans to activate an emergency COVID-response that will aim at providing a malnutrition preventive safety net in the most affected locations. WFP will target the most vulnerable households with pregnant and breast-feeding women and children below 5 years of age in the highest risk COVID-19 districts and will provide unconditional nutrition assistance through a blanket supplementary feeding programme. The households in these districts will be identified with support of the WFP VAM team and in collaboration with other stakeholders. In addition, WFP will strengthen MAM treatment services in line with COVID-19 guideline on continuity for IMAM services. These will specifically be implemented in selected districts with the highest COVID-19 Burden. In these locations, in addition to static health facilities WFP will engage mobile health teams who will extend services to community level with the aim of preventing movement of clients but rather reaching out to them in much smaller groups that can be manged to adhere to COVID-19 prevention measures such as social distancing, use of personal protective equipment and sanitizing . WFP will further ensure that Nutrition assistance and related commodities are provided only once instead of twice a month to further minimize the potential spread of the virus through frequent contact. WFP will also try to ensure that through its cooperating partners, and in collaboration with MoPH, appropriate COVID-19 prevention messaging, hand sanitizing facilities and use of PPEs by service providers are applied and made available at distribution sites to protect both clients and service providers.
This proposal focuses on the procurement of specialized nutritious foods for treatment and prevention of moderate acute in children and PLW (Pregnant and Lactating Women) in the prioritized provinces and districts. With the US$ 1,028,622 from AHF 3rd Reserve Allocation WFP will procure 114 mt AchaMum, 193 mt Supercereal, and 74 mt WawaMum this quantity can cover MAM treatment needs for 12,600 children and 2,640 pregnant and lactating women in the 23 prioritized districts located in the 8 provinces of Farah, Ghor, Herat, Balkh, Badghis, Takhar, Kunduz and Faryab. In addition, about 16,381 children and 4,170 PLW will be reached with preventive nutrition support.
Upon funding approval using its Global Commodity Management Facility WFP will start SNF procurement to reduce lead time. Additionally, WFP may also draw commodity loans from other projects with some existing stocks to cover the needs in the targeted locations for the first 2 - 3 months as the other commodities are secured.

participating-org.narrative: Coordination Of Rehabilitation amp; Development Services For Afghanistan CRDSA

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Delivery of lifesaving nutrition services to COVID-19 priority areas

description.narrative:
The global COVID-19 pandemic has led to immediate serious health concerns. The transmission of COVID-19 is expected to impact on all the conditions needed to sustain good nutrition – household food security, health and nutrition services and caring practices. On 11 March 2020, WHO declared the outbreak of COVID-19 a “pandemic”. Afghanistan confirmed its first case of COVID-19 in Herat province on 24 February 2020, and COVID-19 cases are increasing: to date, there are more than 2,700 confirmed cases in the country. Children and Pregnant amp Lactating Women (PLW) in the COVID-19 high risk districts are identified at a higher risk of acute malnutrition.
The Nutrition Cluster has identified 25 districts at high risk for COVID-19, within ten provinces (Farah, Ghor, Herat, Kunduz, Kabul, Faryab, Balkh, Badghis, Takhar, Nimroz) with pre-existing emergency levels of acute malnutrition, which would need continued provision of nutrition services.
UNICEF, the sole provider of Ready-To-Use-Therapeutic-Food (RUTF) in the country, forecasted a shortage of RUTF for the year 2020. To maintain the current scale of services in the target areas with an acceptable level of treatment coverage, UNICEF is seeking the support of the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund (AHF) to support provision of lifesaving therapeutic supplies (RUTF) to secure Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) treatment services for a total of 20,856 children in the COVID-19 high risk districts.
UNICEF will procure the therapeutic supplies through its Supply Division. Supplies will be stored at national and regional UNICEF warehouses and will be distributed to the implementing partners (IPs) through Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) on a quarterly basis. The AHF project IPs are: Agency for Assistance and Development of Afghanistan (AADA), Bakhtar Development Network (BDN), Sanayee Development Organization (SDO), Association on Higher Education and Disability (AHEAD), Medical Management and Research Course for Afghans (MMRCA), Medical Refresher Courses for Afghans (MRCA), Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance (CHA) also the non-BPHS IPs including World Vision International (WVI), Save the Children International (SCI), and Action Against Hunger (AAH).
UNICEF will use complementary funding sources, including but not limited to the last AHF allocation, to provide therapeutic milk (F-75 and F-100 type) to complement the lifesaving treatment services addressing the needs of children with SAM with medical complications in hospitals in the 25 target districts in the 10 target provinces.
Outpatient and inpatient treatment of SAM are integral components of the Integrated Management of Acute Malnutrition (IMAM) approach, that will be delivered by the Basic Package of Health Services/ Essential Package of Hospital Services (BPHS/ EPHS) and humanitarian implementing partners through fixed health facilities and mobile teams.
Furthermore, SAM treatment will be provided simultaneously with the treatment of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) supported by World Food Programme (WFP), where applicable.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description.narrative:
This project is to build, operationalise and manage a 5 bed Covid-19 Intensive Care Unit (ICU) on the UNOCA compound in Kabul, Afghanistan in order to address the current shortfall in intensive care capacity for the NGO, diplomatic and UN community.
This is an emergency requirement required to encourage the international humanitarian community to 'stay and deliver'.
The project will be implemented and managed by UNOPS. The project has four main pillars as follows:
Building facilities (real estate) for the ICU Medical equipment, supplies and catering for the ICU. Staffing for the ICU Accommodation for the ICU staff
UNOPS has identified an international medical ‘turn-key’ medical provider (Iqarus) with the required infrastructure, equipment, professional medical staff and medicines for Covid-19 treatment.
UNOPS will hire a specialist ICU facility Doctor (IICA2 / P3), separate to Iqarus, to provide quality assurance and medical guidance to UNOPS. The 5 bed ICU unit will be manned 24/7 by on-call doctors, nurses and life support medics. There will be an x-ray capability and a lab technician able to conduct the relevant haematology and bio-chem testing required. There will be an attached laundry to deal with in-house linen and uniform cleaning. There will be an incinerator to deal specifically with Covid-19 clinical waste. There will also be an armoured ambulance and paramedics in order to safely collect patients from outside and bring them to the facility for treatment. The facility will have 5 x patient beds fully equipped with the correct equipment to treat Covid 19 patients requiring intensive care and mechanical ventilation systems in order to save their lives. The equipment and infrastructure provided shall be of the highest international standards in line with WHO guidelines.
The ICU facility will be located right next to the Joint Medical Services (JMS) building on the UNOCA compound in Kabul that will allow for a very practical partnership to grow between the JMS and the ICU facility medical staff. It will also allow the JMS's Chief Medical Officer and other JMS staff to help conduct the relevant quality of health cover checks required for UN staff use as potential patients of the ICU.
In terms of timelines, the project has allocated 3 months after funds are released from the AHF to UNOPS in order to get the ICU assembled and commissioned. However, so much work has gone in to the preparation off official project time, that we should be in a position to complete within a much shorter time period, perhaps two months after funds being received. For example, the turnkey medical provider has been identified as Iqarus. All costs have been confirmed. Stringent design reviews are near completion and will be ready to go by the time funds come on board. All the detail, the planning, and relevant checks and balances have been conducted. The RFQ's are out for the minor works contracts and will be ready to sign off once the money is with UNOPS. Iqarus are already registered and allowed to practice with the Ministry of Public Health. It is now a question of launching the technical output of the project. As soon as the money comes on board, UNOPS is ready to break ground and start the site development.
Mitigation of future delays: 1. Work closely with UNDSS, JMS and UNAMA Mission Support in order to facilitate the ICU construction and operational phases as much as possible. 2. Ensure all Health and Safety guidelines are adhered to strictly. 3. Provide as much support as possible to the contractors to get them on site. 4. Ensure proper financial management is in place to ensure funds are paid out on time in order to allow the contractors to proceed. 5. Ensure all project procedures are in place. 6. Instigate the communications management approach and keep all stakeholders informed of what's going on at all times.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improved mental health and psycho social well being of caregivers and children in Ghor province in response to conflict, disaster and COVID-19.

description.narrative:
Children in Afghanistan, especially those already suffering from poverty and inequity, are among the most vulnerable to the harsh socio-economic impacts of COVID-19. Child mortality, malnutrition, forced marriages, sexual abuse other forms of violence, exploitation, and child labor are all common challenges for the average child. With the addition of COVID-19 and its immediate and secondary impacts, children are now more anxious and worried than ever before and at greater risk of facing physical, sexual and emotional violence, especially as poverty rates and hunger in the country rise. A recent World Vision Assessment titled An Assessment of the Socio Economic Impact of COVID-19 on the Most Vulnerable Families in Afghanistan, has shown that almost 50% of caregivers are suffering from negative psychosocial symptoms due to COVID-19 and 30% of children expressed feelings of sadness related to the pandemic. To mitigate negative coping mechanism and enhance the psychosocial wellbeing of children and caregivers, delivery of specialized MHPSS services, as well as an effective case management system is essential.
In order to ensure sustainability and the capacity of existing community structures is strengthened, WV will focus on working with already formed Faith Leader Forums that comprises of community and faith leaders in Firozkoh, Dowlat yar and Lal Serjangal. In addition, WV will support CPAN with essential capacities related to enhancing the protective environment for boys and girls. The community based approach will include contextualized ToT trainings on PSS, Child Safeguarding and Positive Coping Mechanisms as well as ongoing support in order to empower community leaders and CPAN to have ownership of the program. A specialized MHPSS response will be delivered through awareness sessions and home to home visits, to ensure the most vulnerable caregivers, boys and girls have the opportunity to engage in PSS activities plus receive useful age and gender appropriate information to adopt positive coping mechanisms. Community engagement and risk communications will adhere to guidance shared by the RCCE Working Group.
The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated pre-existing vulnerabilities and further limited access to life-saving services, including case management. The disruption in the environment, socio-economic situation, daily routines and life of the families and communities and the measures put in place to prevent and control the spread of COVID19 heavily affects children’s development and well-being. Case management is an essential service which children must have access to in order to ensure they receive the support and services required while they are at heightened risk of abuse, neglect, and exploitation. WV will assess and strengthen the case management system across Ghor province, to support the service delivery of CPAN and other CP actors to deliver a coordinated and effective case management service, based on lessons learnt, best practice and guiding principles.
Building on established structures, WV will support a total of 4 existing Mobile Health and Nutrition Teams (MHNT) in 3 districts of Ghor. Currently, WV has 2 MHNTs in Firozkoh, 1 MHNT in Dowlat yar, and 1 MHNT in Lal Serjangal. MHNTs provide awareness raising, counseling, treatment, and referrals for mental health and psychosocial disorders using the mhGAP and ISAC guidelines for mental health in emergencies. In addition, WV is currently programming a COVID-19 response in Firozkoh using a community-based approach to mitigate risks and enhance the protective environment of populations. All PSS activities in the project will adhere to the Global Protection Cluster’s Guidelines for Restarting PSS Activities in an Emergency Setting.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description.narrative: War Child Canada will provide psychosocial support to the beneficiaries who have been affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. During the 6 months proposed duration of this project, War Child Canada will provide services to 6,336 individuals in Qarabagh, Dehsabz, Bagrami, and district 5th of Kabul Province. The major activities will include 1) Provision of high-quality PSS support through experienced PSS counsellors, 2) Improve and adjust the already developed PSS tools, IEC materials, and PSS delivery guidelines for PSS counsellors, 3) Establish coordination and collaborative partnership with key stakeholders, 4) Identify vulnerable population under stress and offer home-based PSS, 5) Establish monitoring and evidence-based data system, and 6) Establish SOPs for referral and establish referral linkages with service providers. All these activities are done to ensure the project is meeting the goal which is "To ensure well-being and protection of vulnerable women, men, boys and adolescent girls through provision of quality psychosocial support, and multi-sectoral services in communities of Kabul Province". This will strengthen the protection mechanisms at the community level in all the target districts of Kabul to address the threats of Covid-19 outbreak.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Support to vulnerable households through distribution of cash for protection in Afghanistan

description.narrative: UNHCR will distribute cash assistance AFN 15,500 (approx. USD 195 per family) to 1,400 protection-vulnerable households among IDPs, returnees and host communities impacted by COVID-19 in Afghanistan. This is in response to the needs outlined in section 1 which shows the precarious protection situation of the people in Afghanistan due to COVID-19, exacerbating the already difficult social and economic conditions. Beneficiaries will be selected using existing data. Over the past three years, UNHCR has conducted in-person vulnerability/needs assessments for persons of concern for different cash-based programmes including cash for shelter, support to persons with specific needs, winterization, among others. The vulnerability profile of these former cash recipients is consolidated and maintained by UNHCR. Given the current circumstances where in person or household visits are not feasible, beneficiaries will primarily be selected through a desk review followed by data validation. In identifying the target group for this activity, UNHCR analyzed this data and pre-selected those who met the categorical selection criteria for a phone-based validation interview (conducted by a partner) to verify their basic biodata and presence in the country. The validation of the beneficiary details is carried out by Women for Afghan Women (WAW), Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance (CHA), Organization of Human Welfare (OHW) and BEST, all of whom have existing partnership agreements with UNHCR. The AHF-funded activity will be incorporated into the work of the UNHCR sub offices and staff to ensure the implementation All households with specific profiles were scored as per the categorical selection criteria. Households were assigned a score of one (1) for each risk/vulnerability profile one (1) for not receiving any assistance. Each household’s score was aggregated and ranked in order of priority. This modality was due to limitations in conducting face-to-face interviews, related efficiencies in utilizing existing data and avoiding respondent fatigue, good practices in targeting approaches during pandemics, and existing literature on groups most impacted by COVID-19. The cash is delivered by a Money Service Provider (MSP). UNHCR has ongoing cash-based programmes targeted for a cross-section of populations-in-need and existing distribution sites across the country, with COVID-19 specific mitigation measures, will be utilized. Transmission of COVID-19 at distribution sites is mitigated by several actions ex: distributing cash in secure locations, organizing distribution into smaller distributions over several days, distributing cash in envelops, provision of facilities for handwashing and wearing PPE. UNHCR is responsible for disseminating information on the amounts, frequency, distribution points, dates and times for payments through phone calls and existing community leadership structures. UNHCR staff will be present during the distribution. Should the security situation and other restrictions limit UNHCR staff from being present during the distributions, the same will be monitored remotely by phone, and partner staff will be physically be present to witness the distribution. During the distribution, when cash is handed out, the recipient will be provided a brief awareness session including information regarding the complaints mechanism. Please refer to section 6 for more details. UNHCR has mobilized community support and involved local authorities in the design and delivery of the programme. This ensures adequate understanding of the programme as well as necessary measures are in place to safeguard both programme recipients and humanitarian staff. UNHCR also utilizes secure distribution sites to deliver the cash assistance to beneficiaries. Moreover, complaint mechanisms are in place to continuously raise awareness of the programme to both recipients and non-recipients, and to review any valid comments or concerns, before escalating to conflict.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Community-Based Child Protection and GBV Response in Kandahar province in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The proposed project aims to provide lifesaving and protection assistance to the children, women, girls among the vulnerable IDPs, returnees and host community Dand (Kandahar), Daman, Boldak, Arghandaab and Zhari districts in Kandahar province. Total 14,950 beneficiaries (women-3,600, men-3,000, boys-3,875, girls-4,475) will be reached within the project period through child protection and GBV services.
The project will provide case management services and psychosocial assistance for 4,950 children (boys- 2,475, girls-2,475) who are at risk because of conflict, displacement and recent COVID-19 pandemic. The Psychosocial mobile teams will identify vulnerable children, provide psychosocial support and provide case management services through close coordination with community and local authorities. The project will strengthen child protection referral services through developing understanding and capacity on child protection issues and having an inter-sectoral pathways for the service providers accessible to all these needing assistance. 10 Child Friendly Spaces (CFSs) will be established in IDPs/returnee settlement where children of all abilities don’t have access to recreational activities. 25 Child Protection Forum will be established in community/village level who will be trained and will work for the promoting child protection in their community. Religious leaders, elders, women leaders will be engaged on mobilization of community people on child protection issues.
IRW will provide GBV protection services and awareness among 10,000 individuals (women-3,600, men-3,000, boys-1,400, girls-,2,000) for IDPs, returnees and host communities in Kandahar. IRW will utilize internal capacity to respond through provision of GBV case management and Psychosocial Support (PSS), provision of dignity kits for women and girls, capacity building of service providers and protection monitoring and risk mitigation activities services in the targeted districts of Kandahar province. A key focus of this intervention will include strengthening GBV services for women and girls making them more accessible for all and promoting local level GBV coordination and referral systems with other local and international actors. GBV awareness messages will be disseminated through local FM radio stations to reach wider number of audiences. The project will operate Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHSs) for providing psychosocial support for the women and girls in need. The project will engage community elders, religious and community leaders and youth for sensitizing community people on GBV issues.
IRW will coordination with all key stakeholders including relevant official institutions and government t ministries, as well as others humanitarian agencies in local and national level. IRW has a strong accountability system of Complaint Response Mechanism (CRM), safeguarding and protection from sexual from sexual exploitation and abuse, that reflects its commitments to CHS and IASC minimum standards. All interventions implemented through this project will be based on consideration of safety and dignity, non-discrimination and respect to beneficiaries with their informed consent. IRW will ensure “Do No Harm” principle that guide IRW interventions intervention to avoid causing further harm due to its intervention and priorities beneficiaries security and safety.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting vulnerable girls and boys regain access to education due to COVID-19-related school closures in Jawzjan, Afghanistan.

description.narrative:
Since March 2020, due to COVID-19, Afghanistan has closed its schools for five months leaving 7.5 million children with no access to education. Alternative modalities were put in place to provide education to children, including distance education (through television, radio), self-learning and small group learning but these relied heavily on access to electricity and/or technology, leaving the most vulnerable behind. With the rate of new cases decreasing, the Ministry of Education has started to allow schools to reopen as long as they meet minimum requirements to allow a safe return to learning, including comprehensive protocols and strict hygiene measures to prevent the transmission of COVID- 19. In response to this, ACTED will provide support to 80 schools and 13 CBCs in Mingajik, Aqcha and Fayzabad districts of Jawzjan, reaching 43,174 women, men, boys and girls.
The response will provide 58 primary and secondary schools and 13 CBCs with access to handwashing stations with soap and potable water plus WASH and disinfection kits. In addition, ACTED will provide 43,174 boy and girl students, women and men teachers with two washable, reusable facemasks each across 80 schools and 13 CBCs.
As CBE and schools are unlikely to be able to open straightaway in every case, ACTED will also provide 5,736 vulnerable Grade 1-3 children with self-learning materials so they are able to regain access to education as quickly as possible.
